headline: Blender Hollandaise Sauce
description: This blender Hollandaise is rich, lemony, and delicious. It has all the ingredients of the classic recipe, but it's incredibly quick and easy to make.

video.description: For perfect Hollandaise sauce, break out the blender!
video.name: Blender Hollandaise

name: Blender Hollandaise Sauce

recipeInstructions.text: Combine egg yolks, lemon juice, mustard, and hot pepper sauce in the container of a blender; cover and blend for about 5 seconds.
Place butter in a glass measuring cup. Heat butter in the microwave for about 1 minute, or until hot and completely melted.
Turn the blender on; pour melted butter in a slow, steady stream until sauce is thick and smooth, about 15 to 30 seconds.

review.reviewBody: Best and easiest way to make Hollandaise. Butter must be boiling and blender must be running when streaming in the hot melted butter. You can not add butter all at once, or fail to blend while adding the butter or it will cook and curdle the egg yolk. I omit the mustard and I like sprinkling a bit of paprika on top.

Thank you for this quick, easy & delicious recipe!! I made it this morning for our daughter's birthday breakfast, and she was thrilled. We all thought it was great. I will definitely use this as my go-to from now on!

This is ridiculously simple and works surprisingly well. I use an immersion blender in a tall narrow container, and the only trick is to ensure that the butter is quite hot and you are blending the entire time you are slowly drizzling the butter in. If the butter isn't fairly hot, the egg will not thicken at all. Easy recipe to customize to your family's taste. Today I served it on homemade crab cakes.
Very easy! We didn't have hot sauce or mustard, but it was still very tasty and so simple to make.
It tasted less like hollandaise and more like a Miracle whip. It was ok. Just not what we were expecting.

This recipe couldn't be easier to prepare and is delicious. Heck,it even allows for tweaking to your taste w/o making it difficult. It's up to you to notch it up or down. If afterwards you don't think it was it could have been, that on you then. Just saying.

My first job ever was working breakfast at Tippin’s. Their restaurants have long been out of business, but I have craved their Eggs Benedict after all these years. I always order Eggs Benedict go out to breakfast or when we travel, etc and rarely have had any as good as the version they served. They used Wolferman’s THICK English muffins (amazing and worth every calorie) and this recipe tastes exactly like the hollandaise Tippin’s used. SO good and perfect for a special occasion. For my trial run, I had no real butter on hand so I used yogurt butter and avocado butter and it still turned out amazingly good. So you could make this hollandaise a “little” healthier and be confident it will turn out to be delicious. As another reviewer mentioned, my butter also wasn’t quite hot enough after 1 minute in the microwave. Luckily, I was using a hand mixer and bowl, so I just set my bowl in the pan of hot water I was planning to make my poached eggs in. I continued mixing as the bowl heated up and it set perfectly. Next time I’ll just heat my butter longer, but this method saved the sauce ;). If you love a lot of hollandaise and are planning to serve 4-5+ people, I would absolutely double or triple this recipe. My craving for Tippin’s Eggs Benedict has been satisfied!
Wasnt a huge fan it was just ok
Easy and delicious every time I make it. This is my new go to hollandaise.

EPIC FAIL! Followed the recipe exactly and it did not thicken at all, like not even close to thick. I ended up with runny egg yolks mixed with melted butter. Complete waste of eggs and butter. I will not be trying it again.

Excellent recipe. Contrary to another comment, the tiny bit of Dijon does not detract from the flavor, and it acts as an emulsifier to help prevent the sauce from breaking. I didn't add hot sauce, as that is something that I feel should be added at the eater's discretion after serving.
I was truly surprised! It was fast and easy. Most of all, it taste like is should!

Great recipe. Followed the recipe exactly. I adjusted the recipe yield for 6 servings, but ended up having to double because the yield wasn’t enough for 2 servings of breakfast.

tip:. remember the hot butter is what cooks the egg yolk. so make sure it's really hot when you drizzle it in.
This hollindaise is BOMB! Came out perfect, so thick, creamy and flavorful

this is great! VERY easy and has good flavor and texture but be careful not to blend it too long. I didn't measure the mustard, just added a tiny dash, and left out the hot sauce because I wasn't sure my husband would like it. I did garnish with cayenne pepper and it was wonderful.
I will certainly make this again.
Followed to the letter and it worked well, in the end added extra Dijon because it was super lemony.

I made this for some steamed asparagus because I have been craving a good hollandaise, but they are usually so cumbersome to make and I refuse to do the dry packets. This recipe made it super easy using my food processor and the consistency turned out marvelous - so creamy & no cooked egg pieces! I omitted the dijon mustard since I don't like it/carry it in my house and added an extra egg yolk and an extra Tbsp. of lemon juice per another reviewer's suggestion. The lemon juice was overpowering in my opinion, so I tamed it back with about a teaspoon of Splenda since I'm doing the low-carb thing. I will keep the extra yolk but not add the extra juice next time. This is definitely a keeper and the best/easiest way to make a deliciously decadent hollandaise!
Easy, quick and delicious!

This turned out perfect! I did not have the kind of blender where I could add the butter in a steady stream so added it in bulk and held my breath. Did not seem to matter... it thickened nice and creamy with no lumps! 2-3 minutes max in prep time and so much better than the packaged!

Incredibly easy, just make sure butter is very hot or it doesn't work...

My go to recipe. After heating the butter, I whisk it really well. My hubby works the immersion blender while I pour the butter in a slow and thin stream, which allows the eggs and fat to emulsify and thicken perfectly.

Thank the Lord!! I’ve spent a decade of my marriage attempting to recreate my mother-in-laws Hollandaise for my wife on special occasions. Inevitably I would get my heat wrong with a double boiler. This was easy, quick, 1M times less frustrating.

At the last minute, I cranked up the heat to get the butter bubbly, and was able to easily time this to be ready the moment the asparagus was. For those who had theirs end up runny, I imagine it had to do with the temperature of the butter. Ours was the perfect consistency and texture. Will definitely make again with a tad less lemon.
I loved it! Super easy, fast and foolproof! Next time I will spice it up a bit more with a little cayenne.
Great taste simple to make

Making Hollandaise sauce, because I rarely make it, has always been an intimidating experience to me. I was in a rush this morning, making eggs Benedict. I tried this recipe in order to get brunch on the table quickly. I used a Braun hand-blender. Given the simplicity, speed, and taste, this recipe is a no-brainer. The speed that it all comes together is so quick, I would hold off adding the melted butter in preparing the sauce until your dish is fully plated. The taste of it is so good, I will use this as my default recipe even when I’m not rushed.
Perfection. I used a small single smoothie blender and it was so good and easy!!

This recipe is a very good substitute in a pinch! I usually make the McCormick brand hollandaise sauce because I like the taste and it's easy to do. This was equally as easy and when I had my butter already melted on the stove ready for my packet, I realized I misplaced the packet. So I quickly searched for a quick and easy recipe to compensate. I already had the perfect amount of butter. All I added were the egg yokes, dijon, and the lemon to the blender and then poured in my already hot butter! We didnt have any hot sauce, but I liked the way this turned out. 

I think it almost tastes like McDonalds breakfast sauce, which I'm sad that they discontinued. So now I have a great recipe to use in a pinch or when I crave that same taste!

When I make this next time I will add just a little less dijon as it's quite powerful!

This was so easy and it tasted great! I used a submerging hand held blender which made it easy to make and for easy clean up. I won't shy away from making Eggs Benedict again with this fool proof recipe.

Good, but not out-of-this-world.

Superb!
Excellent flavor!! 
This recepie is a keeper. No need to look any further.
Great hollandaise, easy to make, tastes decadent. Will use this recipe for years to come. I did not put hot sauce in mine. Instead, I used a little cayenne pepper.

I use 4 egg yolks and just add a bit more of the other ingredients and we have just enough sauce for (4) english muffins, 2 half covered english muffins for Eggs Benedict for each of us. If you like more sauce and are making more than 4 muffins (8 halves) you may need to make a double batch.

It is all a matter of taste, make it how you like it, tweak it until you own it. For us, the mustard and hot sauce make this sauce prefect.

I use a large 4 cup Pyrex container right over a burner on the stove adding a little heat as needed. This saves me the extra mess with the blender. If timing is an issue just add a bit of water to reconstitute the sauce and mix and warm as you go. They are egg yolks after all, they will harden a bit if you let them sit after warming the sauce. a little water seems to have had no effect on the taste, I may try milk next time if needed....

A few tips: if you melt the butter in the microwave, heat it on high for one minute covered with a napkin. Let it cool for a moment, then stir it, and heat it another minute on high covered with a napkin. The butter will be super hot when you pour it into the blender.
